div.p: This paper extends the prior work of discrete event-triggered communication for networked T-S fuzzy systems, where the next communication instant is determined by an event-triggered communication scheme with a constant threshold and the premises of T-S fuzzy systems and parallel distribution compensation (PDC) fuzzy control rules are synchronous. Firstly, an adaptive event-triggered communication scheme for NCSs is presented, which relaxes the assumption of the prior work that the threshold of event-triggered communication scheme is a preselected constant. Secondly, an asynchronous premise re-construct method for networked T-S fuzzy systems is proposed, which relaxes the assumption of the prior work that the premises of the plant and the PDC control rules are synchronous. We show that the number of transmitted packets generated by the proposed scheme is smaller than those generated by some existing ones while ensuring the desired control performance. Simulations show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

control systems, the main advantages of NCSs are easy maintenance, low cost, and increased system flexibility [1]. Therefore, much attention has been paid to analysis and design of NCSs during the last decades [2], [3]. Moreover, since the communication bandwidth is a scarce resource, more recently, how to design the reasonable communication scheme for saving the limited communication resources has been also received increasing interest, see, for example [4], [5], [6] and references therein.

In the study of nonlinear systems, Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy models are qualified to represent a class of nonlinear systems, and parallel distribution compensation (PDC) method is a typical approach for T-S fuzzy controller design [7], [8], [9]. For T-S fuzzy systems controlled over a communication network, although there are some publications in the literature [3], [8], [10], [11], [12], notice that periodic communication schemes are the common assumption in the above mentioned works, in which the transmission events are generated as periodic manner. Generally, the selection of sampling period under a time-triggered task model is done before the system is deployed. One has to ensure adequate sampling over a wide range of uncertainties, even though larger uncertainties are rare occurrence. This leads to inefficient implementations in terms of limited resources [13], [?], [15].

Since time-triggered task models may be undesirable in many situations due to its conservativeness, in recent years, sporadic event/self-triggered task models have been addressed for saving the limited computation and communication resources, such as continuous event-triggered communication based on Input-to-State Stable (ISS) stability theory [16], discrete event-triggered communication based on delay system method [17], [18], [19], [20], switched system method [21] and self-triggered communication based on predictive control theory [4], [13]. Notice that a pre-selected constant threshold to determine whether or not to transmit the current sampled data is their common feature. Recently, authors of the paper [22] investigate the delay-dependent stability of networked T-S fuzzy systems with an event-triggered communication scheme, where the current sampled data is not transmitted over a communication network except that the value of a function related with the latest sampled data violates a preselected constant threshold. In [20], an output-based event-triggered communication scheme is proposed for networked control systems with time-varying sampling, however, in which the event-triggered threshold parameter δ is a constant, which cannot be adjusted based on the network and system conditions. In [35], an adaptive event-triggered communication scheme is investigated for a networked linear system with nonlinearities. Nevertheless, the adopted scheme in [35] can be improved since the threshold parameter δ is a predetermined two values function. Moreover, a critical assumption in [22] is that the premises of the T-S fuzzy systems and the PDC fuzzy control rules are synchronous. This means that there is no communication delays when the sampled data are transmitted from the sensors to the controllers, this violates the fact that there is a communication network between the plant and the controller resulting in inevitable delays in the transmissions. In practice, the premises of the T-S fuzzy systems and the PDC fuzzy control rules are asynchronous under network environments. With those "asychronous" premises, the event-triggered communication scheme in [6], [17], [22] cannot theoretically guarantee H ∞ stability of T-S fuzzy systems under network environments. It is, therefore, important to relax this assumption so that event-triggering communication scheme can be applied to a wider class of nonlinear systems for saving limited communication and computation resources.

Based on the above discussions, one can see that the investigation of [6], [17], [22] focuses on traditional event-triggered communication scheme with a preselected constant threshold, while how to design an adaptive event-triggered communication scheme with a dynamically adjustable threshold for saving more limited network resources, as well as how to design and operation of the PDC fuzzy control rules for satisfying the asynchronous premise constraints under network environments, have not been investigated. Also, the stability and stabilization criteria in [22] are deserved to be improved, since there contain too many superfluous free weighting matrices such that the computation efficiency reduces sharply with the increasing of dimension of the studied system, especially when a large number of fuzzy rules are used in T-S fuzzy systems. These issues motivate the current study.

In this paper, we investigate the delay-dependent H ∞ stabilization of T-S fuzzy systems under network environments with an adaptive event-triggered communication scheme and tackle the unsolved problems in [20], [22]. To further reduce the transmitted number, we propose a novel adaptive event-triggered communication scheme. This scheme relaxes the assumption in [22] that event-triggered communication threshold is a preselected constant, but still ensures H ∞ stability of the resulting event-triggered T-S fuzzy systems. The release times of the sampled data are triggered by an adjustable threshold, which can be adaptively adjusted based on the latest available information. We show that the number of transmitted sampled data generated by the proposed scheme are fewer than those generated by traditional event-triggered schemes [6], [22].

We also provide a way to delicately construct the asynchronous premises to tackle the problem of non-uniform time scales in T-S fuzzy model and PDC fuzzy control rules without breaking H ∞ stability of the studied system, therefore, the critical assumption of synchronous premises in some existing ones [10], [11] is no longer needed. As a result, the number of transmitted data over the communication networks is reduced, and the desired control performance is ensured while consuming the fewer communication bandwidth. Moreover, compared with the criteria adopted in [22], two improved criteria with faster calculation efficiency are derived by using Jensen's inequality [23].

This paper is organized as follows. An adaptive event-triggered communication scheme for T-S fuzzy systems under network environments is presented in Section II. An asynchronous premise re-construct method to design PDC fuzzy control rules for T-S systems with asynchronous premise constraints is introduced in Section III. Section IV provides the stability and stabilization criteria for the system under consideration. Section V presents simulation results and Section VI states conclusions.

div.head: II. AN ADAPTIVE EVENT-TRIGGERED COMMUNICATION SCHEME
div.p: In this Section, we will propose a novel adaptive event-triggered communication scheme (AETC) to reduce the number of the transmitted data while preserving the desired control performance. Different from some existing communication schemes with a constant threshold [6], [17], [22], the key feature of AETC is that the threshold condition of AETC can be adaptively adjusted based on the latest available state-dependent information.
Before proceeding further, the following assumptions are needed.

div.head: Assumption 1:
div.p: The sensors are time-triggered, the system states are sampled at a constant period h, and all transmitted packets are time-stamped.

Assumption 2: The controller is event-triggered. Once the control data becomes available, it sends a control packet to the actuator of the control loop. The control packets carry the time stamps of the measurements.
Assumption 3: The actuator is event-triggered with a zero-order-holder (ZOH). The ZOH is used to hold the control input, when there is no the latest control packet arrived at the actuator.

Assumption 4: Network-induced delays from the sensor-to-controller and from the controllerto-actuator, and the computational and waiting delays are lumped together as τ t k , where τ t k ∈ (0, τ ], τ is the upper bound of τ t k .

Compared with some existing event-triggered communication schemes [6], [21], [22], the main advantage of the proposed AETC is that the threshold condition can be dynamically adjusted to save more limited communication bandwidth while ensuring the desired control performance. div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: An adaptive event-triggered communication scheme has been proposed for a class of networked nonlinear system with asynchronous premise constraints. Compared with some existing event-triggered communication scheme in [6], [21], [22], the proposed adaptive event-triggered communication scheme has the advantage to dynamically adjust the event-triggered threshold to save more limited communication bandwidth while guaranteeing the same control performance;

Compared with some existing works on T-S fuzzy systems controlled over a communication network [11], [25], the synchronous premise assumption is no longer needed by constructing an asynchronous premise between the plant and the controller.
